title: Why the Simplest Desktop Agent Abstraction Wins - Bytebot - The Easiest Way to Build Desktop Agents
highlight:
Why the Simplest Desktop Agent Abstraction Wins
Jun 20, 2025
highlights:
Why the Simplest Desktop Agent Abstraction Wins
Jun 20, 2025

There’s a massive category of work that lives in the no-man’s land between APIs and deep internal logic. It’s the gnarly, hard-to-automate workflows that involve:

Jumping between apps

Copy-pasting between SaaS tools

Downloading PDFs, renaming them, and uploading them to different portals

Typing into legacy desktop software that has no public API

Handling authentication, file dialogs, drag-and-drop interactions

highlights: A Brief History of Cursor's Tab Completion

As a solution, Babble was trained on edit sequences instead of lines of code. More akin to what you'd see in a git diff. Since Cursor owns the entire editor, they are privy to the changes initiated, accepted, and rejected by developers in a project, putting them in pole position for training the best tab-completion model.
Jacob was planning to make his own IDE after hitting the limits of a plugin.

title: From: Steve Jobs. "Great idea, thank you." | #haymanSplaining
highlight:
From: Steve Jobs
To: Steve Hayman
Great idea, thank you.

I’ve often thought I should print and frame this email, and let people wonder what the Great Idea was. “We should merge back with Apple!” “How about a music player that fit in your pocket?” “We should build something with a touch screen.” no, nothing quite that cool, but still, it’s one of my favourite messages.
highlights:
From: Steve Jobs
To: Steve Hayman
Great idea, thank you.

I’ve often thought I should print and frame this email, and let people wonder what the Great Idea was. “We should merge back with Apple!” “How about a music player that fit in your pocket?” “We should build something with a touch screen.” no, nothing quite that cool, but still, it’s one of my favourite messages.

title: Podfox: World's First Container-Aware Browser - Home of Val Packett
highlight: odman run --rm -it -p
highlights: odman run --rm -it -p

In the old-school rootful setup, networking is pretty straightforward: the daemon can create bridge interfaces on the host, containers get assigned IP addresses on a bridged subnet, and they are accessible as if they were actual machines. And it’s possible to set up DNS on the host machine to resolve to container names but like… ugh, messing with DNS.
